title: Urgot actually has a ton of utility
body:
- 15% damage reduction for 1 or more targets
- slowing auto attacks that also give him a shield
- armor shredding E
- suppression ult with displacement and damage reduction
- decent poke in lane with Q

Why is he not played support more often? Is it because he needs gold/items to scale well? I mean, I'd just get {{item:3042}} and full tank from there (including {{item:2049}} of course). He could even take {{item:3303}} in lane for the mana regen, since he's somewhat mana-hungry if you spam Q a lot. I just think he's a little bit underrated as a support champ. Maybe that could be his new niche when his rework finally comes?

I've tried him a couple times support. You basically have two options: full tank, or his standard hybrid build. After that you have two main problems with it; first, both builds are quite expensive which lowers your usefulness as either role, and second, he's simply outclassed. You can find a better support to fill either role. I'm still trying occasionally, I'd like to find something to make him work because he does have quite a bit of utility, balancing his build is pretty tough though.

I'm still trying occasionally, I'd like to find something to make him work because he does have quite a bit of utility, balancing his build is pretty tough though.

I especially like his passive for trading in lane. It's like shielding your ADC but better, since a shield can be popped, leaving your ADC with no protection. But his passive is far more consistent damage reduction, and it affects EVERYTHING. You can auto the ADC and Q the support for a total of 30% damage reduction on the enemy, which is almost criminally overpowered IMO. 

For builds, I'd go with something like this: {{item:3042}} {{item:2301}} {{item:3190}} {{item:3025}} {{item:3107}} {{item:1001}}. These items are all relatively cheap; nothing over 3K gold, and getting the SS+Income combo item gives you an additional item slot to work with. I'd probably replace Locket with Black Cleaver if I was really ahead though. Plus, if your ADC ever falls behind, you have the option to build AD yourself and try and replace them.
Actually, it's a total of 15% damage reduction. 15% reduced damage from the ADC and 15% from the support is still 15% overall.

> Actually, it's a total of 15% damage reduction. 15% reduced damage from the ADC and 15% from the support is still 15% overall.

Uh.........no? If you reduce the damage their ADC is doing by 15%, then you also reduce the damage their support is doing by 15%, that's a total of 30% reduction of damage.

Math: Let's say the ADC and Support will both do 100 damage. 

Both get reduced by 15%, so ADC does 85 damage, and Support does 85 damage. 

Instead of 200 damage, they now do a total of 170 damage. 

That means 30 damage was reduced. 

30 is 15% of 200.

If it was 30% reduced damage, you would only take 140 damage (200 - 30%). That means the ADC and Support only did 70 damage each. Which means each of them had to be debuffed for 30% damage reduction.

But Urgot can only debuff for 15% reduction.

How I see it is: here's 15 of something, and here's another 15 of something. Add them up, and you have 30 somethings. In this case, the something is damage reduction. Urgot reduces one target's damage by 15%, and a second target's damage by 15%. So in total, he's reducing damage by 30%; 15% from one source, and another 15% from another source.

Again. If one person would do 100 damage, they are reduced to 85 damage - 85% of 100% damage (100 damage). The second person would do 100 damage, which is reduced to 85 damage - again, 85% of 100% damage (100 damage).

100 damage is 100% for each champion individually. But, when both attack together, they deal a total of 200 damage. So, combined, 100% damage would be 200 damage. Reduced by 15% brings it to 170 damage.

How much damage do the two deal together? 170, based on 85 damage plus 85 damage. 15% damage reduction.

When 2 people's damage is reduced by 15%, their combined damage is reduced by 15%, because the _total_ damage increases.

He's basically like Ezreal though in that he only really NEEDS a Tear for his mana problems. After that, any other mana items he gets are luxury items. Also the Spellthief's line of items will help greatly in-lane with mana regen. Once you've overcome that initial tempo hit of Tear+Sightstone, he can begin to focus on getting damage (if you're ahead) or utility (if you're even/behind).

problem in lies that needing anything is a really big deal when you need to get other things first, and also the fact that trying to find workarounds for a character that can only somewhat do a job is not as good as simply choosing a character that can more easily achieve the same result
